dt: {bc}to drive away or cause to vanish by or as if by scattering {bc}{sx|dissipate||}

pt: {sc}scatter{/sc} {sc}disperse{/sc} {sc}dissipate{/sc} {sc}dispel{/sc} mean to cause to separate or break up. {sc}scatter{/sc} implies a force that drives parts or units irregularly in many directions.
{sc}disperse{/sc} implies a wider separation and a complete breaking up of a mass or group.
{sc}dissipate{/sc} stresses complete disintegration or dissolution and final disappearance.

pt.t: the fog was {it}dissipated{/it} by the morning sun

pt: {sc}dispel{/sc} stresses a driving away or getting rid of as if by scattering.

pt.t: an authoritative statement that {it}dispelled{/it} all doubt

et: Middle English, from Latin {it}dispellere{/it}, from {it}dis-{/it} + {it}pellere{/it} to drive, beat {ma}{mat|felt|}{/ma}
shortdef: to drive away or cause to vanish by or as if by scattering : dissipate
